raw_text:
Barclays profits hit record level
 
 Barclays, the UK's third-biggest bank, has seen annual pre-tax profits climb to record levels boosted by a sharp rise in business at its investment arm.
 
 Profits for the year to 31 December rose 20% to £4.6bn ($8.6bn). Barclays' chief John Varley said the bank had "caught the winds" of a very strong world economy. Earnings at Barclays Capital investment bank rose 25% to £1.04bn, but investment in branch operations held back growth in its UK retail business.
 
 The group is the first of Britain's five big banks to report 2004 results. According to analysts' forecasts, HSBC, the biggest UK bank by stock market valuation, will report profits of £9.4bn later this month.
 
 Barclays results were in line with market expectations. Its Global Investors wing made £347m, an 82% jump on 2003 figures. Profits at Barclaycard rose by 5% to £801m but were said to have been affected by a series of interest rate rises and investment to grow its customer base. The bank also blamed margins pressure on its mortgage business and spending on its branches over the past year for a 1% fall in profits in its UK retail division to £1.13bn.
 
 "The outlook for 2005 is good as a result of balance sheet growth and investments made in 2004," Mr Varley said. Barclays cautioned that growth this year may be slower than in 2004 on the back of softer US and Chinese economies and the impact of interest rate rises on household spending in the UK. It added its bid to acquire a controlling stake in South Africa's leading retail bank Absa, was being considered by regulatory authorities. Speaking on BBC Radio 4, Mr Varley declined to be drawn on reports that Barclays had held merger talks with US bank Wells Fargo. A tie-up between Barclays and California-based Wells Fargo would create the world's fourth biggest bank, valued at $180bn. At 1405 GMT, shares in Barclays were trading down 0.67% at 590 pence. "The headline numbers are in line, but the story is costs," said analyst Alex Potter at Lehman Brothers. "They are a bit more aggressive than we had expected. The cost overshoot is not in Barclays Capital but in the UK bank."
llama3.2:1b: Barclays' annual pre-tax profits rose to £4.6bn ($8.6bn) on record growth boosted by investment at its arm and a sharp rise in business. Profits increased 20% in the year to December, with Barclays Capital rising 25%. The UK bank was the first of Britain's five biggest banks to report results.
llama3.2:3b: Barclays' annual pre-tax profits rose 20% to £4.6bn, driven by strong business at its investment arm, with earnings at Barclays Capital increasing 25%. However, growth in its UK retail division slowed due to margin pressure and spending on branches. The bank's outlook for 2005 is cautious, citing slower growth in the US and Chinese economies and interest rate rises affecting household spending.
gemma2:2b: Barclays reported record annual profits of £4.6 billion due to strong performance from its investment arm, with earnings at Barclays Capital rising 25%.  The bank's UK retail business experienced a 1% decline in profits, attributed to margin pressure on mortgages and investments in branch operations.  However, the group anticipates growth in 2005 driven by balance sheet expansion and investment made in 2004.  Barclays is considering a bid for Absa, and has not confirmed merger talks with Wells Fargo.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Barclays reported profits of £4.6 billion for 2013, up from £3.57 billion the previous year. Profits were boosted by strong growth at its investment arm Barclays Capital and a sharp rise in business operations. The group is the first of Britain's five big banks to report results. Barclays' Global Investors division made £347 million, an 82% increase from 2012 figures. The bank blamed higher interest rates on customer base growth, lower mortgage profits and spending cuts on branches for a fall in retail branch profits. A deal with South African banking giant Absa was considered by regulators. Shares in Barclays fell to 590 pence at the end of trading on 6 August.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Barclays' pre-tax profits jumped to record levels due to investment growth and improved business, despite a 1% drop in its retail division's profit. Analysts forecast HSBC will report £9.4bn earnings later this month. The British bank is considering acquiring South Africa's leading retail bank Absa.
qwen2.5:3b: Barclays saw record pre-tax profits of £4.6bn ($8.6bn) for the year ending 31 December, driven by strong business at its investment arm. Profits increased 20% to £4.6bn, with Barclays Capital showing a rise of 25%. However, UK retail operations faced challenges due to interest rate rises and branch investments. Analysts forecast that HSBC will report profits of £9.4bn later in the year. Despite market expectations, Barclays reported an 82% increase in Global Investors' profits at £347m. The bank's UK retail division saw a marginal drop in profits to £1.13bn due to mortgage margins pressure and branch expenses. CEO John Varley expects positive growth for 2005 but anticipates slower expansion due to economic conditions, including weaker US and Chinese economies and interest rate impacts on household spending. Barclays also considers acquiring South Africa's Absa bank, though this deal is pending regulatory approval. Analysts highlight the need to address cost pressures in addition to headline profits.

Barclays profits hit record level

Barclays, the UK's third-biggest bank, has seen annual pre-tax profits climb to record levels boosted by a sharp rise in business at its investment arm. The group reported earnings that rose 20% to £4.6bn ($8.6bn) during the year to 31 December. Barclays chief John Varley said the bank had "caught the winds" of a very strong world economy. Earnings from Barclays Capital investment bank increased 25% to £1.04bn, but investment in branch operations held back growth in its UK retail business.

The group made the first of Britain's five big banks to report 2004 results. According to analysts' forecasts, HSBC, the biggest UK bank by stock market valuation, will report profits of £9.4bn later this month. The results were in line with market expectations. Barclays Global Investors wing made £347m, an 82% jump on 2003 figures.

Profit at Barclaycard rose by 5% to £801m but were said to have been affected by a series of interest rate rises and investment to grow its customer base. The bank also blamed margins pressure on its mortgage business and spending on its branches over the past year for a 1% fall in profits in its UK retail division to £1.13bn.

The outlook for 2005 is good as a result of balance sheet growth and investments made in 2004. Mr Varley said. Barclays cautioned that growth this year may be slower than in 2004 on the back of softer US and Chinese economies and the impact of interest rate rises on household spending in the UK.

At 14.05 GMT, shares in Barclays were trading down 0.67% at 590 pence. The headline numbers are in line, but the story is costs to another bank, said analyst Alex Potter at Lehman Brothers. They are a bit more aggressive than we had expected. The cost overshoot is not in Barclays Capital but in the UK bank.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Barclays profits hitting record levels. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Barclays was the third biggest bank in the UK, and they hit record profits. They boosted that with strong economic data from elsewhere. John Varley said the economy is strong, so Barclays is catching its winds.

They had a £1.04bn profit at their investment bank, but growth in retail businesses didn't hold back as much. The group is the first of five banks to report results this year. HSBC is expected to report later this month with £9.4bn.

Barclays's profits were in line with expectations. Their investment wing made £347m, up 82% from before. Profits at Barclaycard went up 5%, but had interest rate rises and customer growth as issues. They blamed margins on mortgage business and spending on branches causing a 1% dip in the UK retail division to £1.13bn.

They said future growth will be good because of better balances and investments, but mentions slower growth this year due to softer US and Chinese economies, plus interest rates affecting spending in the UK. They're considering a merger with Wells Fargo for fourth place in $180bn.

Mr Varley called it "good" for balance sheets and investments, but worries about costs. Analysts expect a bit more than they thought from HSBC in May.

So I need to condense all this into a concise summary without explanations or formatting. Just the key points: Barclays hit record profits, boosted by strong global economy, specific gains at their investment arm, expected growth from other banks, some cost issues but outlook positive.
</think>

Barclays, the UK's third-largest bank, achieved record annual pre-tax profits of £4.6bn due to a sharp rise in its investment arm, driven by a strong global economy as reported by John Varley. The group is the first of five big banks to report results and was expected to report profits later this month. HSBC, the biggest UK bank by valuation, is set to report £9.4bn in April. Barclays's profit growth at its investment bank was up 25%, while retail business growth held back slower than before. The bank experienced interest rate rises affecting margins on its mortgage business and spending on branches. Analysts expect a 1% dip in the UK retail division, but they noted a £1.13bn profit after a 20% increase from the previous year. The outlook is positive due to balance sheet growth, supported by investments in 2004, though concerns about costs and slower growth are raised.
tinyllama:1.1b: Barclays, the UK's third-largest bank, recorded record annual profit levels boosted by a sharp rise in business at its investment arm. Profits for the year to 31 December rose 20% to £4.6 billion ($8.6 billion), despite a weaker global economy. Barclays Capital investment bank recorded a 25% increase in earnings, while investments in branch operations held back growth in its UK retail business. The group expects to report profits of £9.4 billion later this month, according to analysts' forecasts. Barclays' Global Investoers division made £347 million, an 82% jump on 2003 figures, while profits at Barclaycard rose by 5% to £801 million. The bank warned margin pressures on its mortgage business and spendings in its branches over the past year may have impacted profit growth this year, but said it was confident of achieving a return to profitability in 2005 as balance sheet growth continues.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Barclays' (BARC) record-breaking profits of £4.6 billion for the year to December pushed them past rival HSBC to be Britain's largest bank, while Barclays Capital's pre-tax profits increased by 25% to £1.04 billion. The investment bank's earnings also surged, increasing by 25% to £1.04 billion. Despite the strong performance in the UK retail business, Barclays reported lower profits in its UK retail division compared with previous years. In a major breakthrough for the bank, Barclays Capital investment bank's earnings also increased during this period by 25% to £1.04 billion.

Varley stated that the bank's profitability and business growth has been fueled by "catching the winds of a very strong world economy." Although the outlook for 2005 is considered good, Barclays' growth was slower than in 2004 on the back of interest rate rises and investments made in the UK retail division. The bank also noted that growth this year may be slower than in 2004 due to a combination of factors such as balancing its investment portfolio, improving margins, and potentially acquiring another major bank.

The analysts' forecasts suggest HSBC will report profits of £9.4 billion for the year ended December. In comparison, Barclays has outperformed the market this year with its record-breaking profits of £4.6 billion. This impressive performance has driven the bank's bid to acquire a controlling stake in South Africa's leading retail bank Absa. The tie-up between Barclays and Wells Fargo is also being considered by regulatory authorities.
phi:2.7b: Barclays, one of the largest banks in the UK, reported record pre-tax profits for the year ending 31 December 2004, with an increase of 20% to £4.6bn. Profits at Barclays Capital investment bank rose 25%, while its UK retail division experienced a 1% decline due to interest rate rises and branch expenses. Despite slower growth than in the previous year, Barclays expects the outlook to be positive thanks to balance sheet expansion and investments made in 2004. However, regulatory authorities are currently reviewing their bid to acquire South African retailer Absa. The news was reported as positive by investors, with Barclays' shares down 0.67% at £590 per share by 15:05 GMT. The report highlighted that while the overall profits were in line with market expectations, costs had increased more than anticipated, which could affect future growth.
orca-mini:3b: Barclays, the UK's third-biggest bank, reported record annual pre-tax profits of £4.6bn ($8.6bn), boosted by a 20% rise in business at its investment arm. Profits at Barclays Capital increased 25% to £1.04bn, but the bank's UK retail business was held back by increased spending on branches and higher interest rates, resulting in a 1% fall in profits in its UK retail division to £1.13bn. The group cautioned that growth this year may be slower than in 2004 due to softer US and Chinese economies and the impact of interest rate rises on household spending in the UK, but it added that its bid to acquire a controlling stake in South Africa's leading retail bank Absa was being considered by regulatory authorities.

However, growth in 2005 may be slower than in 2004 due to softer US and Chinese economies and interest rate rises' impact on household spending in the UK. Barclays also cautioned that its bid to acquire a controlling stake in South Africa's retail bank Absa is being considered by regulatory authorities.

Barclaycard profits rose 5% to £801m, though impacted by interest rate hikes. Barclays Global Investors posted an 82% profit jump to £347m. CEO John Varley expressed optimism for 2005 but warned of slower growth due to economic conditions and interest rate effects. The bank's bid for a controlling stake in South Africa's Absa is under regulatory review. Barclays declined to comment on merger talks with US bank Wells Fargo. This surge was primarily driven by Barclays Capital's investment arm, which saw earnings rise 25% to £1.04bn. However, investments in branch operations and mortgage business margins pressure impacted UK retail profits, falling 1% to £1.13bn. The bank's Global Investors wing made an impressive £347m, an 82% increase from the prior year. Barclaycard's profits grew by 5% to £801m but were affected by interest rate rises and branch expansion costs. Chief John Varley anticipates a strong 2005 outlook due to balance sheet growth and 2004 investments, though he cautioned potential slower growth amid softening US and Chinese economies and UK spending constraints. Barclays is also exploring a merger with South Africa's Absa bank. Analyst Alex Potter noted that while headline numbers aligned with expectations, the company had more aggressive cost overshoots than anticipated, particularly in its UK operations.
